name: Lake Quinault Lodge

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed June 2013, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Olympic National Park is not like Mt. Rainier. There are no lodgings with views of spectacular peaks, though we could see some snowcapped peaks in the distance. This is a place for relaxing, with some walking and hiking opportunities nearby. On one way we drove to the Hoh Rainforest Visitors Center and walked there. Also dropped by a couple of beach areas just up the coast. We also took a 3-4 hour van and walking tour, through a concessionaire, from the lodge (cost about $30 pp and was worth it; when we later went to the Hoh area, we didn't worry about taking the ranger walk with large crowds). Thank goodness there is no "fairytale town" here. The lodge is on national forest land, very close to the border of the national park, and adjoins land owned by a local Native American tribe (they control access to the lake and while swimming was allowed, including from floating docks, boat trips had been at least temporarily curtailed due to the tribe's complaints about environmental problems).
reviews.title: Relaxing with nice views

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed July 2013, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The lodge is not inexpensive by any means. By the time we booked, the choices were traditional rooms, with fireplaces, in one of the original buildings, or rooms in the recently renovated wing. As it was mid-summer and I knew my wife sometimes doesn't like the most rustic of places, we chose the latter. We were happy with our choice, though some may prefer the other rooms as they are, according to the receptionist, a bit larger. Our wing was 3 stories high, with no elevator but with ramps rather than stairs, so taking luggage upstairs wasn't burdensome. There were high fir trees in back of our room, so we had privacy. From our small balcony in back we could get a nice view of the lake.
reviews.title: Charming but some things to know....

reviews.text: When you arrive you will see a notice that while Wi-Fi coverage is available in most rooms, cell phone coverage is very spotty at best. And there are no phones in the rooms, to foster quiet and serenity (though our room had a large flatscreen TV). We had to walk to the lawn area in back of the main lodge to get any cell phone coverage and even that could be spotty at times. There are pay phones in the lodge, just off the beautiful wood lobby (which had a fire going at all times).
reviews.title: Beautiful Location
My return visit still held surprises!
reviews.text: There are snacks available in the reception area, and a basic café across the street (we had lunch there once, but service was very, very slow). The Roosevelt Room, open for breakfast, lunch and dinner, is good, and with nice views of the grass area and a bit of the lake, but is a bit expensive. Our best dinner was at the Salmon House, at the Rainforest Lodge about a mile up the road.

reviews.title: Beautiful and Peaceful
reviews.text: I slept well every one of the 3 nights we spent there. My wife said that on one night our neighbor talked late into the night. Parking can get tight especially right in front of the lodge. We did not have time to use the indoor pool in the lodge and felt it was a bit cool to swim, especially in the morning (we were usually busy throughout the day).

We stayed at the Lake Quinault Lodge for 3 nights in late July 2013. Our family had rooms 215 and 217 in the main lodge, which had great views of the lake. Here is what we particularly liked about the lodge:
reviews.title: Great location, nice place to mix rest with outdoor activities.

reviews.text: 1. Location. The lodge is right on the lake, and is next to trailheads for several very nice short hikes through the rainforest. We also drove to the coast (40 minute drive) and to the Hoh River Valley (1 1/2 hours) for more extended hikes.
reviews.title: Lake Quinault Lodge - Always a Treat

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed June 2013, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: 2. Amenities. We purposefully stayed in rooms in the main lodge because we enjoy the traditional old "Parkitecture" rooms of the National Parks (such as the Ahwahnee, the Old Faithful Inn, El Tovar, etc.). (We stay in plenty of fancy modern rooms on our business trips, so staying in a more traditional room adds to the vacation feel.) The main room is wonderful with its massive fireplace, piano, and comfortable chairs where guests like to sit to read, play games, and chat. Outside, there is a large green lawn between the lodge and the lake with Adirondack chairs and low-key lawn games, perfect for children and adults who want to relax. There is also an indoor sauna and pool and a game room. The only disappointment was the recent closing of the lake to boating. (The Quinault tribe is currently working with biologists to try to fix some environmental problems caused by the rotting docks around the lake.)
reviews.title: The main lodge is beautiful...

reviews.text: 3. Restaurant and bar. The lodge restaurant was enjoyable for breakfast and dinner. We particularly liked the sweet potato pancakes for breakfast. One evening, we couldn't get a reservation in the restaurant until 8 pm, but then realized that we could order "take-out" from the restaurant earlier and eat it outside on the wonderful patio overlooking the lawn and the lake. For our third night, we drove the 40 minutes to the restaurant at the Kaloloch Lodge on the coast, which was a nice change of pace. We also enjoyed the lobby bar window for ordering coffee drinks, wine, beer and cocktails. The bartender had created a number of her own cocktail recipes with local color names, such as the "Big Foot."
reviews.title: Modern rooms in a National Park

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed July 2013, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We have been coming to the Lake Quinault Lodge for many years and this is one of our favorite destinations of all time. The lodge is historic and so beautiful and in such a great setting. We typically stay in the boat house so we can take our dog but we have stayed in all of the different parts of the lodge on earlier visits. The boathouse rooms have new mattresses, pillows and linens and are very good for sleeping.The lodge is well kept, the grounds are very well taken care of and the food in the restaurant is very good as well. There's not much else to tell, we will be coming back here for a very long time.
reviews.title: Beautiful setting, relaxing, extremely enjoyable

reviews.text: Now that I look at the traveler photos for LQL, I feel silly. I booked a lodge room, 214, thinking that we would be in a comfortable, pretty room. We were not. Apparently, there are many pretty rooms elsewhere on the property. If only I'd known, we might have enjoyed our stay more.
reviews.title: Strange room

reviews.text: Our room:
reviews.title: For room with view, see below!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed June 2013, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The walls were painted a mossy green, the bed covers amounted to sheets (no bed runners or welcoming comforter) and had a strange decorative pillow on them. Not welcoming at all. The dresser was cumbersome and there was little place to store our stuff. This was made worse by the fact that our sink was in the main room, exactly where we wanted to store our things. There was no closet, but there was a small hanging rack near the bathroom. The small bathroom was very basic but modern. I got a fine night's sleep, and was comfortable enough but I wondered about the value. When I told my friend that the room cost about 220 after all fees/taxes, she was surprised. She was so unhappy she said she wished we could have stayed in Portland during our last night. She also wondered why it could be so cool outside but so warm in our room, even with the screen open. I can't explain that one, but it bothered her.
reviews.title: Great weekend getaway - Cozy & inviting

reviews.text: Overall, I wasn't quite as unhappy as she, but I do agree that it was much more comfortable to be out of the room than in it. The lovely common area, wonderful restaurant, and delightful grassy area provided a welcome respite from a claustrophobic room.
reviews.title: Step back in time

reviews.text: Note: My ankle was badly injured by the time we got here, so we were pretty much grounded at the resort. If my ankle was not so damaged, I would have suggested a hike or the rainforest tour. I'd stay here again if I knew I'd be hiking/seeing the area. To "hang out", though, probably not.
reviews.title: lovely place; excellent tours

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed August 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We wanted to spend a long weekend in the Olympic National Park and decided to divide our time between Lake Quinault Lodge (two nights) and Crescent Lake Resort (one night). Both places are rustic. Lake Quinault lodge is the less rustic of the two in that it has a TV in the room (no TV, no phone at Lake Crescent) but Lake Crescent was by far the better choice for us.
reviews.title: Plain Jane at a Cinderella Price

likes.liked: — View of the lake from our table in the dining room.
likes.disliked: — Over priced for the quality of the rooms.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed September 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The setting at both places was beautiful. However, Lake Quinault suffers from that fact that a storm blew down many, many trees in the forest around them. When we saw the forest from the highway we were very disappointed as it looked like there wouldn't be any good hiking in the immediate area. It turns out that we did enjoy hiking around there but you certainly do have to allow for the downed trees.
reviews.title: Hotel Management Malpractice

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed August 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The Lodge itself promises more than it delivers, at least in my experience. There is a problem with a bit of noise in the rooms. We had a downstairs room and I didn't like the fact that we couldn't lock the screen door (we had a patio/sliding door). This meant when we went to bed we had the choice of either sleeping with the door closed or leaving the door open and not even having a locked screen door. Many places now days have it where you can lock the door open a couple of inches to let in air (there is no air conditioning here) but that wasn't an option here. I did request a portable fan from the front desk and was told one would be delivered but it never arrived and I gave up.
reviews.title: It is a lodge, not a hotel

reviews.text: There are a number of activities besides hiking. We did some kayaking and completely enjoyed it, but beware that the rentals close relatively early.
reviews.title: Lovely setting, cramped quarters

reviews.text: One of the nights we were there there was a wedding in the courtyard area of the hotel and a reception followed. This really didn't bother us until some of the guests became intoxicated and started yelling. Thankfully our room was far enough away that we didn't hear much. I happened to be out taking a walk when another guest finally asked them to hold the noise down; the hotel staff should have taken care of this since it was loud enough that they heard it and it was very obvious that some of the guests had had way, way too much to drink (how many times can you scream, "Here comes the bride!" without everyone in the hotel knowing you're drunk?).
reviews.title: Great location, great food, well worth it, but a small suite for four

likes.disliked: — suite was small for family of four

reviews.text: My flight to Seattle from Washington, D.C. was canceled the day I was to stay at the lodge and I was unable to make it. I called the lodge the morning of my day of arrival and canceled. Because it was within 72 hours, I had to forfeit all of my reservation, $173. This was for a Friday night stay in mid-summer and I'm sure they could have filled the room. But they said that didn't matter, I'd forfeit the whole thing anyway. Unfortunately, Aramark has these rip-off policies because they are managing properties in national parks that are in high demand, so they think they can get away with it. Book elsewhere if you can.
reviews.title: ARAMARK rip-off

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed July 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: This lodge, which has been featured on PBS's "Great Lodges of America's National Parks," is in a magnificent setting on Lake Quinault on the border between Olympic National Park, Olympic National Forest, and the Quinault Indian Nation. The place oozes history. You can take several hikes right from the lodge or participate in horseshoes, boating, swimming, and just relaxing. Boat tours and guided nature hikes are available. Food at the Roosevelt Restaurant is great, but you can also walk across the street to the Mercantile for cheaper meals or groceries.
reviews.title: My Favorite Spot in Washington State

reviews.text: In keeping with the inn's historic nature, the rooms in the inn itself (as opposed to the annex and other buildings) are pretty old-fashioned but definitely clean and adequate. The lakefront rooms have a great view, of course.
reviews.title: A good place to be based for rainforest exploration

likes.disliked: — Rooms were spartan, service was spotty

reviews.title: Loved Lake Quinault Lodge
reviews.text: This is a great place to station yourself if you want to explore the Quinault rain forest.. The rooms are definitely adequate, but don't expect luxury The lakeside rooms are apparently the nicest - but are still quite basic. They do have televisions, but no telephones. The deck is tiny - but useful for drying wet hiking clothes in the summer. There is a separate building between the lake house and the main lodge where they accept pets - this has a huge wraparound porch...so if you're going with other people and want a nice place near your rooms to enjoy the view, this is it. The lodge common rooms are quite nice, with a fireplace, overstuffed chairs and sofas, and wifi. There's also a bar area, a game room, a pool and saunas. The lawn and lake view are fabulous. There are hiking trails accessible from the lawn, and also a trailhead across the street. The National Forest Service building is next door, which is great for checking the status on hiking trails (important because of storms and fallen trees).

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed June 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Service at the Lodge is pleasantly flexible - we booked the lake boat tour one afternoon, but 3 members of our party hadn't returned from hiking yet, so they happily switched our party of 8 tour to the following afternoon.
reviews.title: Relaxing at Lake Quinault Lodge

likes.disliked: — It was warmer than normal for a couple of days, so the lack of AC was a small problem at night.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed July 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Of my 3 week holiday in the US and Canada the Lake QUinault Lodge was at 216 dollars the most expensive hotel I stayed in. Unfortunately it wasn't the best, and I would even have to see it comes close to being the worst. I guess it all depends on what you like in a hotel. As for me I like large, modern, comfy rooms with large windows offering nice views, large soft beds, and spacious modern bathrooms. Lake Quinault Lodge is the exact opposite of all that, at least the room where I was staying was. I was staying in a lakeview room, but it was hard to enjoy the view through the small and low window which had been sealed with a mosquito net. Add to that some creaky wooden floors in the room and the corridor, and you get the picture.
reviews.title: Old rooms with creaky wooden floors

likes.liked: — Dining room with good food and great views

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed June 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: I may have been better off if I had not stayed in the main lodge building but in the more recently built annex, which is made of concrete, has large windows viewing the lake and features the small balconies that an earlier reviewer referred to. But I came to Lake Quinault in mid-summer and made my reservation only one day in advance, so I guess I should be glad to have found a plasce to stay at all. Restaurant services were good, and I enjoyed both dinner and breakfast (while enjoying the large windows and great view from the dining room).
reviews.title: Serenity plus

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed June 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: All in all I can't say it is a bad hotel. You just need to be someone who enjoys this kind of authentic atmosphere. But even for those people I would recommend trying to get hold of a room in the newly built annex to the lodge!
reviews.title: Great Place to Stop & Relax

likes.disliked: — Only had a partial lake view.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed August 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Nestled in the rainforest, this is a wonderful place to visit with family and friends. The lakeside setting is movie set perfect and the aura of the Lodge rates A+++. Our room was tidy and clean and even had a TV which was a surprise since most rustic lodges keep things au naturale. Will return to this fabulous Lodge and fine dining experience in the Lodge restaurant.
reviews.title: I wont be back!
Disappointed !
reviews.text: My husband and I had a two night, three day vacation in Olympic National Park. We chose to stay at Lake Quinault Lodge because we love NP lodges and it's location on the SW side of the park helped us with our time constraints. We stayed in a king size, lakeside room and found it to be perfectly adequate and above average for national park lodging. The room was clean, had a TV/VCR, tub with shower and hair dryers. We had a partial lake view with a small balcony. The best part of the stay was it's location. From the lodge you could enjoy the beautiful lake and take an very peaceful, early morning canoe ride. There were also several nice, easy trails nearby. (Our room had walking sticks for use). In the evening there was a nice campfire to enjoy next to the lake. Amenities were better than expected with a nice dining room and convenience store on the grounds. We wished we could have stayed longer but had a lot more to enjoy in the short amount of time we had.

reviews.title: Great place, great people!
reviews.text: We stayed a couple of nights in this place and had a wonderful experience. I can see why the Lodge could be over-crowded during the summertime, but in early October it was just perfect.

Great, spacious room overlooked the lake, plenty of parking, and delicious food in the dining room that was moderately priced. Great people worked there, the kind that are happy to see you and make your stay comfortable.
reviews.title: Quite and Peaceful spot

likes.disliked: — Everything - including local food - is closed by 9pm.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed June 2013, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Booked a lakeside room. Had a quiet room on topfloor with balcony and a nice view of the lake.
reviews.title: Beautiful lodge, wonderful setting

reviews.text: The lodge and setting are very beautiful. The rainforest further on the road is also very beautiful.
reviews.title: Great!

reviews.text: Our lakeside room was large but very basic, no fridge, no ironing board. Had dinner in hotel on the first night, but there is a much much better restaurant one mile further up the road also with scenic view of the lake.
reviews.title: Scenic beauty with a charming, peaceful vibe

reviews.text: Next to the lodge there is a small shop and restaurant for breakfast (cheap and not bad at all)
reviews.title: tranquility

reviews.text: We had a nice rate for 3 nights and would stay again next time.
reviews.title: Best lodge near/in Olympic national park!

reviews.text: We stayed here on a Tuesday and enjoyed every second of our stay. The Rain Forest around the lake is really spectacular. We had our dog along for vacation and we were only allowed to stay in The Boat House. My son thought it was going to be like a garage or something bad, but it was really nice. We had a nice size room with great views and a really cool deck right outside the room door for enjoying the wonderful grounds at the lodge.
reviews.title: Wonderful Stay at Quinault Lodge

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed July 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We went to the Salmon House for dinner and it was ok, but not like alot of the reviews stated. The view from the dining room is very pretty, it overlooks Lake Quinault and a grassy beach. We saw a gaggle of geese in some marshy area there. We went back to the lodge and took a look around the lodge grounds and insides. It has a indoor pool and a very nice lobby with lots of seating. The campfire was going and the wind was blowing off the lake making for a great sunset. Before bed we went to the lounge/bar and got a yummy drink called The Quinault Steamer. We sat there in the lobby and reflected on all we had seen that day. We ate breakfast in the Roosevelt dining room and it was good but the service was very slow. My only complaint was there was no plug in the bathroom to use the hair dryer. The mirror in the room was hung too high for me to see what I was doing and the lighting was poor in that area .It was not a big deal. The Boat House was way more than I expected and I would stay there again in a heartbeat.
reviews.title: It Grows on You

reviews.text: In April, I made a reservation at Lake Quinault Lodge for a Fireplace Room with a king bed at a rate of $250+ per night. Immediately upon making the reservation, my credit card was billed for one night at this rate, plus taxes.
reviews.title: Where Reservations Don't Mean a Thing

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed August 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: When my husband and I arrived in August, we were given the keys to a queen room in the cheaper Lakeside area. After complaining, we were given a key to a king room next door in the same section, and told we'd have to check back the next day with a manager to see if we could stay in that room! The flakey desk clerk made no mention of it being a cheaper room, and made no attempt to contact a manager!
reviews.title: Pleasant rooms, but noisy and not cheap

reviews.text: After studying the property map and my email confirmation, we tried to call the front desk to ask about changing into the correct room grade. The desk clerk put me on hold when I asked for a manager, and then hung up the phone! We finally gave up and walked back to the office to get an explanation of why we didn't receive the reservation we had paid a deposit for. After receiving no help from the front desk, we had to ask for a manager who advised that there were no Fireplace Rooms available, but we could stay in the Lakeside King for our two-night stay. When I pressed about the rate differential, the staff said it would be changed to a rate of $208.
reviews.title: An Amarzing Hotel with an Amazing Location!!!

description: At ground zero for exploring Washington's Olympic National Park.
